Fig. 1 PXRD pattern of CuO nanoparticles. Fig. 2 TEM images of CuO microsphere. Fig. 3 TEM image of CuO nanorods (a) TEM image with electron diffraction pattern and growth axis as inset and (b) HRTEM image with corresponding FFT inset. Fig. 4 Variation of E α with respect to reaction progress computed by (a) Friedman's and (b) Vyazovkin's method. Fig. 5 Isothermal decomposition of AN and AN in presence of CuO nanorods. Fig. 6 The possible ammonia adsorption mechanisms on CuO surface. Fig. 7 The possible mechanism of the adsorbed ammonia surface reactions. Table 1 Kinetic constants for decompositions reaction of AN and AN–CuO mixtures computed by different methods. Ammonium nitrate [%] Catalyst (CuO) [%] Peak decomposition temperature (TG@10°C) [°C] E α Friedman method [kJmol−1] E α Vyazovkin method [kJmol−1] E α coats Redfern [kJmol−1] A coats Redfern (s−1) 100 0 242.3 93.7 90.6 106 2.2×1010 99.5 0.5 242 90.8 89.1 100 6.3×109 99 1 240.2 85.7 82.2 97 2.6×109 98 2 237.2 78.9 75.1 95 1.5×109 Kinetics and mechanism of hydrothermally prepared copper oxide nanorod catalyzed decomposition of ammonium nitrate Anuj A. Vargeese ⁎ Krishnamurthi Muralidharan 1 School of Chemistry and Advanced Centre of Research in High Energy Materials, University of Hyderabad, Hyderabad 500 046, India ⁎ Corresponding author. Present address: Department of Chemistry, National Institute of Technology Calicut, Calicut 673601, Kerala, India. Tel.: +91 495 2285301/406 6794919; fax: +91 495 2287250/402 3012460. 1 Tel.: +91 406 6794919; fax: +91 402 3012460. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Monoclinic CuO nanorods with aspect ratio ∼5 were hydrothermally synthesized. ► Catalytic decomposition of ammonium nitrate in presence of CuO nanorods were studied. ► Kinetic parameters for the catalytic and noncatalytic decomposition were computed. ► Advanced model-free and model-fitting methods used to compute kinetic parameters. ► Possible removal of NH3 by surface reactions changes the decomposition pathway. One of the key aspects in the development of materials science is the synthesis of particles with specific size and morphology for catalytic applications. Nowadays, nanostructured materials with specific morphology are gaining great importance in the field of catalysis. Thin, one-dimensional, monodispersed CuO nanorods with a significantly higher aspect ratio of 5, were successfully prepared by the hydrothermal method with subsequent ultrasonication. The formation of pure monoclinic CuO nanorods was confirmed by powder XRD and SAED. The CuO nanorod growth mechanism is investigated by using TEM and further characterized by FTIR, UV–visible spectroscopy and thermogravimetry. The catalytic decomposition of ammonium nitrate, an environmental friendly rocket propellant oxidizer, over the synthesized CuO nanorods was investigated. The thermal kinetic constants for the catalytic and noncatalytic decomposition of ammonium nitrate samples were computed by using model free (differential and non-linear integral) and model fitting approaches. The catalytic influence was evident even with 1% catalyst concentration. The model fitting method suggested contracting cylinder mechanism as the effective mechanism for all the investigated samples. Apparently, the CuO nanorods provide Lewis acid and/or active metal sites, facilitating the removal of ammonium nitrate decomposition inhibition species such as NH3 and thereby enhance the rate of decomposition. Keywords CuO nanorods Ammonium nitrate Reaction kinetics Catalyzed decomposition Surface reactions 1 Introduction Over the past couple of years, nanoscience and nanotechnology have been attracting worldwide attention and they constitute an active, frontier research area. Synthesis of nanostructured materials with specific size and morphology has recently gained much attention in the material science. Compared with the size control, morphology or shape control is more demanded by the chemical industry. Indeed the application of nanostructured materials is extended to almost all conceivable fields of science, ranging from products of everyday use to rocketry. This demand has stimulated the exploration of new phenomena leading to a technological revolution. A number of recent investigations have shown that, the catalytic activity of nanostructured materials depends on not only their sizes but also their shapes [1–4]. Hence, for catalytic applications the control of shape in addition to size of material is of significant importance [5–7]. An understanding of the mechanism involved in the formation of such nanostructures has been recognized to be of great potential in the production of engineering materials. Thus, with greater understanding of the formation mechanism, catalyst particles of controlled size and morphology can be produced by such methods of synthesis. CuO is a p-type narrow band gap (E g =1.2eV) semiconductor and the band-gap is highly dependent on the morphology and the particle size of the material [8]. CuO, in micro as well as nanoscale, has been widely investigated as heterogeneous catalysts in many important chemical processes [9–13], especially in the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of ammonia. CuO is also used as pigment, fungicide, metallurgy reagent, gas-sensors, magnetic storage media, electronics, lithium batteries, and solar cells owing to its photoconductive and photochemical properties [14]. Due to the extensive practical applications of this material, the synthesis of nanostructured CuO has attracted considerable attention from material scientists. Due to the outstanding properties of one dimensional (1D) nanostructured materials, nanorods are highly demanded by the chemical industry. Even though various synthesis methods are reported in literature to control the morphologies and microstructures, hydrothermal method is the simple and probably the most feasible method to prepare one-dimensional nanoscale materials [15–18]. As the crystal growth is anisotropic, it is prone to grow slowly toward one-dimensional direction under the hydrothermal conditions, such as high pressure and temperature [19]. In the present work, we report a bottom-up approach to prepare 1D CuO nanorods via the hydrothermal method followed by ultrasonication. Transition metal oxides (TMOs) significantly influence the thermal decomposition reactions and such ability of TMOs have extended their application as propellant burn rate modifiers [9,20–24]. Reportedly, the effect of TMOs on the solid state decomposition reactions are influenced by the crystal structure, methods of preparation, impurities, and defect structure of the oxides [23]. The catalytic effect of TMOs on the thermal decomposition may be attributed to many reasons, such as semiconductor properties (degree of p or n nature), charge transfer process or electron transfer process [23,24]. Ammonium nitrate (AN) is widely used as fertilizer, mining agent and oxidizer in gas generator propellant formulations. Since the combustion products of AN does not contain noxious halides harmful to the atmosphere, it is considered as an environmentally benign oxidizer. However, the hygroscopic nature, low energetics and the near room temperature polymorphic transitions limit the application of AN in solid rocket propellants [25]. The application of TMO catalysts can surmount the low reactivity and low energetic of AN and the catalyst efficiency can be increased by reducing their particle size. Even if a substantial increase in reactivity of the chemical decomposition reactions by nanocatalyst assistance might be anticipated, such catalytic decompositions are often dependent on the material property of the nanoparticles. In the present study, the structure, morphology and growth mechanism of the produced CuO nanorods and the performance characteristics of this nanostructured material as a catalyst for the decomposition reaction of AN are discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The chemicals used for the experiments were of commercial (Merck India Ltd.) AR grade and used without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of CuO nanorod catalyst Hydrothermal method using copper acetate and urea [26,27] to synthesize CuO microparticles were extended for the preparation of CuO nanorods. In a typical synthesis, copper acetate monohydrate (Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O) and urea were dissolved in deionized water to prepare the precursor solution of 0.025M. 10mL each of the precursor solutions were mixed, then transferred to a 20mL Teflon-lined stainless steel pressure reactor. The pressure reactor was then kept in an oven at 130°C for 1h. After the heat treatment, the pressure reactor was allowed to cool down to room temperature (∼5–6h). The product obtained after the reaction was washed via centrifugation–redispersion cycles, with each successive supernatant being decanted and replaced with ethanol. Collected CuO particles were dried under reduced pressure at room temperature for 30min. The method produced microspheres composed of nanorods (as per TEM). The microspheres were redispersed in ethanol, and ultrasonic agitated for 3h in a 320W bath ultrasonicator. As a consequence of prolonged ultrasonication the microspheres were disintegrated to nanorods and dispersed in ethanol. The resultant colloidal solution was again dried under reduced pressure and used for further experiments. 2.3 Characterization of CuO nanorods catalyst The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern was obtained using a ‘Bruker D8 Advance’ instruments at room temperature (25°C) and the sample was scanned over a 2θ range of 30–70°. A step size or sampling interval of 0.001° and a scan time of 4.56s was used for the characterization. From the obtained PXRD patterns, the interplanar distances (d) were calculated by Bragg's equation and compared with the JCPDS data. The HRTEM study was carried out on a FEI Tecnai G2 F20 S-Twin Transmission Electron Microscope. The samples for TEM and HRTEM analyses were obtained by diluting the dispersed solution with ethanol and then placing a drop of the diluted solution onto a Formvar covered copper grid and evaporated in air at room temperature. 2.4 Thermal and catalytic decomposition of ammonium nitrate over CuO nanorod catalyst AN–nano CuO rods mixtures with varying molar ratios 99.5:0.5, 99:1 and 98:2 were prepared by blending on a mechanical stirrer for 12h. Crushed and sieved particles of AN in the size range of 105–180μm was used for the experiments. After preparation, the mixture was dried over fused calcium chloride under reduced pressure for 30min and used for decomposition kinetic analysis and catalytic activity evaluation. Thermal or catalytic decomposition experiments of AN were carried out under nitrogen atmosphere in a TA instruments SDT Q600 TGA instrument. In all experiments, ∼1mg of sample was loaded in an open 90μL alumina pan and heated. Nitrogen at a flow rate of 100mL/min was used as the purge gas. Following ICTAC recommendations [28], TG measurements were used to compute the thermal kinetic constants from model free method. The non-isothermal TG runs were conducted at heating rates 2.5, 5, 10 and 20°C/min and the extend of conversion (α) has been computed from the weight loss data using the standard method as described elsewhere [29]. Δα of 0.01 and Δα of 0.025 were respectively used to compute the activation energy from the differential and the integral methods. For comparison and plotting, constant Δα values were shown at an interval of 0.05. Isothermal runs were carried out on the SDT Q600 instrument by keeping the sample at 180°C for 1h. 2.5 Kinetic analysis Two model free (isoconversional), Friedman's differential [30] and Vyazovkin's non-linear integral [31], methods, and a model fitting, Coats–Redfern [32] method was employed for the computation of kinetic parameters and kinetic analysis. The third degree approximation proposed by Senum and Yang [33] has been used in the present study to evaluate the integral in the Vyazovkin's method. Twelve different reaction models were employed in the Coats–Redfern method to estimate the possible decomposition mechanism. The theoretical background of kinetic analysis and the reaction models used are given as Supplementary data. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of CuO nanorod catalyst The facile hydrothermal method and subsequent ultrasonication was employed for the preparation of CuO nanorods. Under the hydrothermal conditions, such as high pressure and temperature, H2O act as a catalyst and occasionally as a component of reaction [34]. The interaction of hydroxyl group with decomposed urea (R1) produces CO2 (R2), that further forms carbonate ions in water. The hydroxyl groups then react with the salt in the cationic solution [35]. The hydroxyl ions concentration and accordingly the pH of the solution increases due to the dissociation of the in situ formed NH4OH (R3). (R1) CO(NH2)2 →NH3 +HNCO (R2) HNCO+H2O→NH4OH+CO2 (R3) NH4OH→NH4 + +OH– The hydrolysis of Cu(CH3COO)2, majorly promoted by the hydrolysis product of urea, results in the precipitation of Cu(OH)2 as small nanorods or nanoflakes at short reaction times. The time required for the appearance of Cu(OH)2 increases due to the connection of (010) planes through H-bonds and with increasing initial copper concentration as a consequence of the pH buffering effect of Cu2+. In the following hydrothermal period, Cu(OH)2 lose H2O molecule by breaking the interplanar H-bonds, resulting in the formation of monoclinic CuO nanostructures [36]. Further evolution of Cu(OH)2 depends crucially on the initial copper concentration, even though this transformation takes place when practically no residual Cu(II) is left in the solution. At low initial Cu(II) concentrations, the transformation of Cu(OH)2 into tenorite occurs without any significant change of particle morphology [37] to nanorods. This transformation would have presumably occurred within the given reaction time. The synthesized CuO nanorods were characterized by Powder XRD, TEM, FTIR, UV–visible spectroscopy and thermogravimetry (TG). The PXRD pattern of monoclinic CuO nanorods, shown in Fig. 1 , was compared with JCPDS 05-0661 and found that the strong peaks were intact. However, due to the anisotropic peak broadening, related to crystallite shape, defects, and microstrain, occur in nanomaterials, very close by peaks corresponding to h k l values 002 and 1 1 1 ¯ as well as 200 and 111 could not be resolved. The 100% intensity peak observed at 2.52Å was intact with respect to the JCPDS data. However, the relative intensity or maximum count per second (cps=250) was less indicating lower degree of crystallinity (preferred orientation) in the nanocrystals. TEM images of the as prepared samples, obtained via hydrothermal method and the sample resulted after ultrasonication were recorded. Interestingly, before ultrasonication the particles showed microsphere morphology. The inset of Fig. 2 shows the microspheres formed during the hydrothermal synthesis. Further, at higher magnifications (Fig. 2) the TEM image suggests that the morphology of the microspheres is actually composed of self-assembled nanorods. When the hydrothermally synthesized microspheres were dispersed in ethanol and ultrasonic agitated, well separated CuO nanorods were obtained. Monodispersed CuO nanorods with uniform length as well as breadth were revealed by the TEM image shown in Fig. 3 . As observed in the TEM, the dimensions of the produced nanorods were ∼50nm in length and ∼10nm in breadth. The SAED pattern obtained for CuO is shown as inset of Fig. 3. The HRTEM image showing the lattice fringe pattern indicated the formation of very thin CuO nanorods. The discrete intense spot in SAED pattern indicate the possibility of single crystal CuO nanorods. Indicating the presence of fewer numbers of single crystallites in the selected area, the SAED pattern showed diffraction rings. The SAED patterns demonstrated the CuO nanorod growth axis to be parallel to (110). The interplanar distances calculated from electron diffraction pattern were in good agreement with the ones obtained from PXRD. Since the method does not employ any template or capping agent, the OH− ion concentration in the reaction solution must be the key factor controlling the growth rate of different crystal faces eventually leading to the formation of anisotropic particle morphology such as nanorod. The CuO particles morphology indicates the growth of (110) face of nanorods was preferred during the hydrothermal treatment. This has been supported by the TEM investigation, which never indicated the presence of small individual particles with different morphology. Even one of the earlier investigations report that, the nanorods synthesized by other methods, if exposed to hydrothermal treatment further grows and did not change the morphology [9]. The small monoclinic CuO nanostructure could grow into bulk nanorods or nanoplatelets as sufficient growing time and appropriate environment was provided. Since particle with other than nanorod morphology was hardly found in the TEM investigation, presumably the nanorod growing/formation time is less than the provided reaction time. As the nanorods have high surface energy or van der Waals forces, they tend to aggregate in spindle-like bundles, similar to the bundles of single wall carbon nanotubes [16]. Even, the role of different self-assembly driving mechanisms, such as, surface tension, and hydrophobic interactions cannot be ruled out in the present context. Considering a similar situation hundreds of nanorods would have compactly self-assembled to form the microparticles as observed in the TEM image (Fig. 2). The spokes observed at the edges of the microparticle evidently supports this conclusion. The shape of the crystal is normally related to the intrinsic unit cell structure and is determined by the outside embodiment of the unit-cell replication and amplification [38]. The diverse morphologies of CuO crystals, such as nanorods or nanoflakes, arise due to the differences of the crystal faces in surface energy and external growth environment. The growth rate of a crystal face is usually related to its surface energy and the fast growing faces have high surface energies and they will vanish in the final morphology and vice versa. This treatment assumes that the equilibrium morphology of a crystal is defined by the minimum energy resulting from the sum of the products of surface energy and surface area of all exposed faces (Wulff rule). The structure of the growing crystal surface at its interface with growth medium has an important bearing on the particular mode of crystal growth adopted. It is possible that the hydroxyl groups could interact with the growing crystal face and alter the growth pattern resulting in nanorod morphology. In the ultrasonication method, the CuO microspheres dispersed solution was irradiated with ultrasonic waves resulting in agitation. Sound waves propagate into the liquid media result in alternating high-pressure (compression) and low-pressure (rarefaction) cycles. During rarefaction, high-intensity sonic waves create small vacuum bubbles or voids in the liquid, which then collapse violently (cavitation) during compression, creating very high local temperatures [39]. Under such high stress conditions and very low concentration, of the order of a few microspheres, the surface energy or van der Waals forces may not suffice to hold the self-assembled nanorods. This will eventually result in the separation of the self-assembled microspheres into the constituent nanorods. Apparently the tendency of the separated nanorods to self-assemble into microspheres cannot be ruled out. However, the low concentration might be a big factor which restricts this back clustering. Hence, the development of crystalline CuO nanorods can be considered as a three stage process, the growth and dissolution of intermediate Cu(OH)2 nanostructures being the first one, alongside the precipitation of CuO nanostructures being the second. In the third step the agglomeration and coarsening of CuO nanostructures occur resulting in CuO nanorods. After the nanorod formation, they self-assemble to form the microparticle. The as-prepared CuO samples were also characterized by FTIR, UV–visible spectroscopy and TG, and the respective images are given as Supplementary data. The UV–visible spectra showed the presence of a maximum absorption peak at 220nm, blue-shifted relative to that of the corresponding signal for bulk CuO, in agreement with prior work [40]. This blue shift is assigned to the quantum size and confinement effects. The FTIR spectrum obtained for the CuO nanorods showed the characteristic absorption peaks corresponds to the CuO stretching vibrational modes at 590, 499 and 424cm−1. The values match with the reported values 587, 478 and 414cm−1 [41]. Compared to the standard absorption spectra of CuO, the observed values in the present studies showed slight variations, probably due to the small crystalline size of the synthesized CuO nanorods. Apart from the above absorptions, the spectrum exhibited significant broad absorption peak at 3430, 1581 and 1398cm−1, indicating adsorbed water and CO2 molecules. The TG of the CuO nanorods were carried out from room temperature to 500°C, and the measurement indicated a total weight loss of ∼10%. The weight loss occurred in the 130–330°C temperature region and then became constant, indicating complete removal of the surface adsorbed moieties. 3.2 Catalytic decomposition of ammonium nitrate AN–nano CuO mixtures with CuO content viz., 0.5, 1 and 2% were prepared as described in the experimental section and the TG data were collected. To identify the lowering in the peak decomposition temperature, a primary evidence of catalytic activity, both TG and differential thermogravimetry (DTG) curves of different compositions measured at 10°C/min heating rate (Fig. 4 of supplementary data) were compared. The comparison revealed that, the peak temperature is significantly lowered with respect to the concentration of the nanocatalyst. In fact the onset of decomposition of AN with 2% CuO nanorods is ∼115°C, which is notably lower than the value obtained for the pristine AN. 3.2.1 Model free (isoconversional) kinetic analysis It is well accepted that addition of catalyst lowers the activation energy of the reaction. Activation energy may be correlated to bond energy data [42] and is generally considered as a measure of the energy barrier to a controlling (rate limiting) bond rupture or bond redistribution step [43]. Activation energy can provide reasonable information about the critical energy needed to start the decomposition reaction of the compound. Since all other parameters are kept similar and assuming that the reaction rate at a constant conversion depends only on the temperature (isoconversional principle), a reduction in the activation energy can be directly related to the catalytic activity of the compound under investigation. The isoconversional methods of kinetic analysis permit to explore the multistep kinetics of the thermal decomposition reactions and helps in drawing mechanistic conclusions about the process [44,28] and even to determine the thermal stability of material under investigation [45]. The activation energy for the decomposition reaction of pristine AN and AN–CuO mixtures were calculated for the comparative assessment. The apparent activation energy (E α ) values of the decomposition reaction of AN and AN–CuO mixtures computed by Friedman's [30] differential isoconversional method and Vyazovkin's [31] non-linear integral isoconversional method were plotted against extend of conversion (α) and are shown in Fig. 4 a and b respectively. In the present study, the activation energy computed by Vyazovkin method for AN yield a value of ∼90kJmol−1, which is in good agreement with the reported value [46]. While a significant reduction in the activation energy was observed for the decomposition reaction of AN in presence of CuO nanorods. The plots of E α against α of AN and AN with 0.5% CuO nanorods were nearly similar indicating no appreciable catalytic activity. However, with 1% and 2% CuO nanorods the activation energy was significantly lowered indicating a strong catalytic activity. The independence of activation energy on the extent of conversion indicates the possibility of single reaction mechanism (or the unification of multiple-reaction mechanisms). However, for the catalyzed decomposition reactions, the activation energy showed a dependence on the extend of conversion implying a possible change in the decomposition reaction pathway. Even though the trends were similar in the dependence of E α with α, the numerical values of activation energy obtained using differential and integral methods showed slight differences. For comparing the activation energy values obtained by different methods, a confidence interval of 95% was invoked [46]. The confidence interval for E α values from Friedman's method for AN, and AN with 0.5, 1 and 2% CuO nanorods are 89–91, 88–91, 81–84 and 72–73kJmol−1 respectively. While the confidence intervals for the activation energy values obtained from Vyazovkin's method are 90–91, 89–90, 82–83 and 75–76kJmol−1 respectively. Based on these statistical observations the difference in the numerical values computed by different methods seems to be negligible. However, these negligible variations could be due to the approximation of the temperature integral that were used in the derivations of the relations of integral isoconversional methods. Hence, irrespective of the difference in numerical values the studies show a strong activity by the nano-CuO rods on the catalytic decomposition of AN. 3.2.2 Linear model fitting (Coats–Redfern) kinetic analysis To get more insights into the mechanism of the decomposition reaction of AN, a model fitting approach, Coats–Redfern method [32], was employed. Owing to the fact that Coats–Redfern is a single curve method and the activation energy derived using this method returns unreliable results [47], no attempt was made to compare the activation energy values obtained by this method. Twelve different reaction models (g(α)) were used for the analysis of the experimental data to obtain the most probable decomposition mechanism [29]. To choose the possible mechanism, the goodness of fit, estimated by highest correlation coefficient was used. The analysis, consistent with the literature [47] suggested that the model of contracting cylinder (statistically equivalent model) remains the most probable mechanism for all the samples. The thermal kinetic constants obtained by different methods are tabulated in Table 1 . However, for the determination of actual decomposition mechanism, accommodating more possible mechanisms rather than the reported common mechanisms (Table 1 of supporting information), a combined kinetic analysis employing a model fit method based on simplified Sestak–Berggren equation can be utilized [28,48]. The preliminary studies using this method show some variations from the result obtained by using Coats–Redfern method. 3.2.3 Isothermal decomposition and residue analysis To rule out any effect of temperature on the decomposition reactions and the catalytic activity, isothermal decomposition of the samples were performed (Fig. 5 ). Since the isothermal method also follows a non-isothermal pattern till the system achieves the required temperature, to avoid any uncertainty, the sample was heated at 20°C/min heating rate to 180°C and then held the sample under the isothermal conditions. The samples with nanocatalyst took lesser time for decomposition demonstrating the catalytic activity of CuO nanorods. The observations clearly substantiate the catalytic activity results obtained by the isoconversional methods. Also, the percentage conversion (non-isothermal) of AN and AN–CuO mixtures with respect to time as well as temperature against the extend of conversion are shown in the Supplementary data. Evidently the non-isothermal study also suggests that the decomposition reaction in presence of the CuO nanorods are completed in lesser time as well as at lower temperature with respect to catalyst concentration. Finally, to ascertain that the CuO nanorod act as a catalyst for AN decomposition reaction and not reacting with it, the residue obtained after catalytic decomposition (method described in Supplementary data) was characterized by PXRD (Fig. 7 of supplementary data). The PXRD pattern confirmed that the residue is CuO, as the major higher intensity peaks corresponding to miller indexes (002), (111), ( 2 ¯ 0 2 ) and (220) were precisely observed. A large hump, caused by the X-rays reaching the sample holding substrate through the thin sample, between 20 and 45° is observed in the PXRD pattern. Since the quantity and the degree of crystallinity of sample was less, the relative intensity/maximum count per second was correspondingly less, and in turn the hump intensity is visibly higher. 3.2.4 Mechanism of catalytic decomposition Even though, the literature reports a variety of decomposition reaction pathways that AN can undergo [49], it is widely accepted that the thermal decomposition is initiated by the vaporization of melted AN accompanied by an endothermic proton transfer reaction (R4). Considering the fact that the DTA curve exhibited endothermic nature of the decomposition, and all other reported decomposition pathways are exothermic in nature [49], the possibility of reaction shown in (R4) seems apparent in the present context. In the non-catalyzed AN decomposition, NH3 and HNO3 are formed in the first step (R4), then the HNO3 further dissociates to smaller species (R5). In fact, existence of species such as HNO3, NH3, N2O, H2O and NO2 has been proved by the earlier investigators using spectroscopic techniques such as FTIR [50,51]. (R4) NH4NO3 →NH3 +HNO3 (R5) 2HNO3 →H2O+NO2 +NO+O2 Since the CuO and ammonia interactions are well known [10], it is quite reasonable to anticipate surface reaction on the CuO nanorods. As illustrated in Fig. 6 , the ammonia molecule can be adsorbed on the surface of CuO [52] by hydrogen-bonding via one of its hydrogen atoms to a surface oxygen atom (or to the oxygen of a surface hydroxyl group), hydrogen-bonding via its nitrogen atom to the hydrogen of a surface hydroxyl group or coordination to an electron-deficient metal atom (Lewis acid site). If compared with the existing literature, the reaction pathway may be explained basing on the formation of intermediates. Presumably the CuO surface reactions can promotes the breakdown of NH3 to smaller species and therefore, the dissociation products are removed at a comparatively faster rate. According to the Le Chatelier's principle, the equilibrium (R4) is displaced to the right, and in turn will encourage the dissociation of AN. Hence, this catalytic interaction and a possible change in the decomposition pathway might be anticipated. As per the literature the adsorbed ammonia undergoes an endothermic dissociation reaction on the adsorbed surface of TiO2 (101), Fe (100), Ni (100), etc. and similar reactions might be facilitated by the CuO (110) nanorods of this study. As shown below, the adsorbed NH3 on the nanocatalyst give rise to N2 through the decomposition of hydrazine produced by the dimerization of NH2 species (R6)–(R8) [53–55]. However, the description of the observed variation by kinetic equations of the Langmuir–Hinshelwood type may not be possible. Since along with the dissociation and decomposition of AN, adsorption also takes place with increase of temperature, the parallel-reaction mechanism may get converted into a parallel-consecutive-reaction mechanism. The proposed surface reaction mechanism is schematically represented in Fig. 7 . (R6) NH3 →NH2 +H (R7) 2NH2 →N2H4 (R8) N2H4 →N2 +H2 It has been demonstrated by the earlier investigators that, NH3 and H2O inhibit the AN decomposition and on the other hand HNO3 promotes the decomposition [56]. The surface active sites on CuO nanorods adsorb the gaseous reactive molecules formed during the dissociative sublimation process of AN and facilitate the removal of inhibiting species such as NH3. During dissociative sublimation of AN, HNO3 is desorbed more rapidly from the AN crystal surface than NH3, which causes incomplete oxidation of ammonia, creating a saturated atmosphere of NH3 as in the case of AP [57]. Hence in presence of the catalyst, the evolved gases might have undergone further reactions on the catalyst surfaces consequently lowering the activation energy of the process. In this way, the CuO nanorods would have supported the complete oxidation of ammonia, brought down the activation energy and promoted the rate of decomposition of AN. 4 Conclusions Nano sized CuO rods of monoclinic phase has been synthesized by the hydrothermal method followed by ultrasonication. The nanorods resulted after hydrolysis, compactly self-assemble to microsphere morphology due to the high surface energy. The ultrasonication process breaks down these self-assembled microspheres to its constituent nanorods. A growth axis parallel to (110) was confirmed for the nanorods by the SAED pattern analysis. The activation energy of decomposition reaction of AN in presence of CuO nanorod catalyst, computed by model free methods illustrates a substantial lowering, suggesting catalytic activity. Approximately a difference of ∼15kJmol−1 in the activation energy for the decomposition reaction of ammonium nitrate in presence of 2wt.% of CuO nanorods was recorded. Presumably, the CuO nanorods assist the removal of AN decomposition inhibition species such as NH3 by providing Lewis acid and/or active metal sites and thereby enhances the reactivity and the decomposition rate. The model fitting approach reaffirms the model of contracting cylinder as the most probable decomposition mechanism. The findings suggest that the application of CuO nanorods in the catalytic decomposition reactions in general, and especially for solid propellant oxidizers eventually leading to the application as burn-rate catalyst for environmentally benign solid propellant systems. Though, apparently the catalytic effect is clearly evident and contracting cylinder model controls the catalyzed and noncatalyzed decomposition of AN, further investigation of the evolved gases in detail using infrared or mass spectroscopy are essential to ascertain the actual reaction mechanism and the role of CuO nanorods that controls the decomposition of AN. coredata.dc:description: One of the key aspects in the development of materials science is the synthesis of particles with specific size and morphology for catalytic applications. Nowadays, nanostructured materials with specific morphology are gaining great importance in the field of catalysis. Thin, one-dimensional, monodispersed CuO nanorods with a significantly higher aspect ratio of 5, were successfully prepared by the hydrothermal method with subsequent ultrasonication. The formation of pure monoclinic CuO nanorods was confirmed by powder XRD and SAED. The CuO nanorod growth mechanism is investigated by using TEM and further characterized by FTIR, UV–visible spectroscopy and thermogravimetry. The catalytic decomposition of ammonium nitrate, an environmental friendly rocket propellant oxidizer, over the synthesized CuO nanorods was investigated. The thermal kinetic constants for the catalytic and noncatalytic decomposition of ammonium nitrate samples were computed by using model free (differential and non-linear integral) and model fitting approaches. The catalytic influence was evident even with 1% catalyst concentration. The model fitting method suggested contracting cylinder mechanism as the effective mechanism for all the investigated samples. Apparently, the CuO nanorods provide Lewis acid and/or active metal sites, facilitating the removal of ammonium nitrate decomposition inhibition species such as NH3 and thereby enhance the rate of decomposition.
coredata.dc:title: Kinetics and mechanism of hydrothermally prepared copper oxide nanorod catalyzed decomposition of ammonium nitrate
